extendedIngredients.name: oregano
extendedIngredients.original: 2 teaspoons chopped fresh oregano or 1 teaspoon dried
extendedIngredients.originalName: chopped fresh oregano or 1 teaspoon dried

extendedIngredients.name: swordfish steaks
extendedIngredients.original: 2 pounds swordfish steaks, cut 1/2 inch thick

title: Swordfish Sicilian-Style
summary: Swordfish Sicilian-Style might be just the main course you are searching for. This recipe serves 4. Watching your figure? This caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal recipe has 450 calories, 45g of protein, and 29g of fat per serving. For $5.3 per serving, this recipe covers 29% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. 1 person were impressed by this recipe. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes about 20 minutes. Head to the store and pick up lemon juice, olive oil, pepper, and a few other things to make it today. To use up the table salt you could follow this main course with the Chocolate Chip Banana Bread Plus Sweet Banana Roundup as a dessert. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 69%. This score is solid. Try Swordfish, Sicilian Style, Swordfish, Sicilian Style, and Sicilian-style Swordfish for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are great choices for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. One wine you could try is GIFFT by Kathie Lee Gifford Pinot Grigio. It has 4.8 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 15 dollars.

productMatches.title: GIFFT by Kathie Lee Gifford Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: GIFFT Pinot Grigio bursts with lively pear and tropical fruits, balanced by crisp acidity and an elegantly refined freshness. Featuring ripe stone fruit and citrus aromas, this wine showcases melon, nectarine and Meyer lemon flavors that finish light and refreshing.

instructions: Light a grill or preheat the broiler. In a small bowl, mix the lemon juice with the salt until the salt dissolves. Stir in the oregano. Slowly whisk in the olive oil and season generously with pepper.                                              Grill the swordfish steaks over high heat (as close to the heat as possible), turning once, until cooked through, 6 to 7 minutes. Transfer the fish to a platter. Prick each fish steak in several places with a fork to allow the sauce to penetrate. Using a spoon, beat the sauce, then drizzle it over the fish. Serve at once.

steps.step: Light a grill or preheat the broiler. In a small bowl, mix the lemon juice with the salt until the salt dissolves. Stir in the oregano. Slowly whisk in the olive oil and season generously with pepper.
Grill the swordfish steaks over high heat (as close to the heat as possible), turning once, until cooked through, 6 to 7 minutes.
Transfer the fish to a platter. Prick each fish steak in several places with a fork to allow the sauce to penetrate. Using a spoon, beat the sauce, then drizzle it over the fish.
